{{good article}} {{Infobox song | name = Heaven | cover = Heaven Inna.jpeg | alt = Inna appears on the single cover wearing a black and white blouse with her hand barely touching her chin. | type = single | artist = [[Inna]] | album = | released = 10 June 2016 | format = [[Music download|Digital download]] | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = {{flatlist| *[[Dance-pop]] *[[tropical house]] }} | length = 3:26 | label = [[Roton (label)|Roton]] | writer = {{flatlist| *[[Axident|Andreas Schuller]] *Leroy Clampitt *[[Play & Win|Sebastian Barac]] *[[Play & Win|Marcel Botezan]] *Laila Samulesen *Trey Campbell *Theea Eliza Miculescu }} | producer = {{flatlist| * Sebastian Barac * Marcel Botezan }} | prev_title = [[Rendez Vous (Inna song)|Rendez Vous]] | prev_year = 2016 | next_title = [[Gimme Gimme (Inna song)|Gimme Gimme]] | next_year = 2017 }} '''"Heaven"''' is a song recorded by [[Romanians|Romanian]] recording artist [[Inna]]. It was released for [[Music download|digital download]] on 10 June 2016 through [[Roton (label)|Roton]]. The recording was written by [[Axident|Andreas Schuller]], Leroy Clampitt, [[Play & Win|Sebastian Barac]], [[Play & Win|Marcel Botezan]], Laila Samulesen, Trey Campbell and Theea Eliza Miculescu, while production was handled by Barac and Botezan. A [[dance-pop]] and [[tropical house]] recording, the single was generally acclaimed by [[music journalism|music critics]], who praised it as an [[earworm]] with Middle Eastern influences. While reviews noted lyrics in English, French, and Spanish, the singer explained that the refrain was written in a language she invented with her label. At the 2017 [[RRA Awards 2011|Radio România Actualități Awards]], "Heaven" was nominated in three categories. An accompanying music video was posted onto [[YouTube]] on 7 June 2016 after a teaser premiered on 3 June 2016; it was shot by John Perez in Shangri-La, [[Mauritius]], in April 2016. The clip portrays Inna at a seaside resort community with a love interest, played by Mauritian actor Olivier Phineas Boissard. To promote the single, Inna performed in Mauritius, and sang "Heaven" in stripped-down versions for Romanian radio stations. The track was commercially successful in Eastern Europe, peaking within the top ten in Bulgaria, Romania and Poland. ==Background and release== "Heaven" was written by [[Axident|Andreas Schuller]], Leroy Clampitt, [[Play & Win|Sebastian Barac]], [[Play & Win|Marcel Botezan]], Laila Samulesen, Trey Campbell and Theea Eliza Miculescu, while production was handled by Barac and Botezan.{{cite news|url=http://www.spanishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Inna&titel=Heaven&cat=s|title=spanishcharts.com – Inna – Heaven|publisher=Spanish Charts. Hung Medien|accessdate=24 November 2016}} The single was released on 10 June 2016, three days after the premiere of its clip.{{cite news|title=Heaven (Radio Edit) – Single by Inna on iTunes|publisher=iTunes Store|date=7 June 2016|accessdate=14 June 2016|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/heaven-radio-edit-single/id1123682881}} The upcoming premiere of a second version of the song, featuring a "well-known" artist, was announced, but never materialized. Several remixes of the track were also made available for consumption as stand-alone releases or on a remix extended play. About the track, Inna said that she was "very happy to release 'Heaven'. It is one of the songs which [she] fell in love with after the first hear and one which [her] fans waited for impatiently. It's the ideal sound for the summer and [she hopes] you will enjoy it."{{cite news|url=http://www.realitatea.net/inna-a-lansat-piesa-heaven-are-sute-de-mii-de-vizualizari-deja_1945162.html|title=Inna a lansat piesa "Heaven". Are sute de mii de vizualizari deja.|date=8 June 2016|publisher=Realitatea|language=Romanian|trans-title=Inna has released the song "Heaven". It already gained thousands of views.|accessdate=1 July 2016}} ==Composition and reception== {{Listen|pos=left|filename=Heaven_(Inna sample).ogg|title="Heaven"|description=A 17-second sample of "Heaven", a [[dance-pop]] and [[tropical house]] song.|format =[[Ogg]]}}While El Broide of ''People Magazine'' wrote that the single is performed in English and French,{{cite news|author=El Broide|title=Jam Of The Day: Inna – Heaven|url=http://www.peoplemagazine.co.za/entertainment/jam-day-inna-heaven|accessdate=1 July 2016|publisher=''People Magazine''|date=27 June 2016}} website Aficia's Valentin Malfroy noted that Spanish is also incorporated, also pointing out a male voice providing vocals for the refrain sung with a strong African accent.{{cite news|author=Malfroy, Valentin|title=Inna: "Heaven", son nouveau single aux multiples influences!|url=http://www.aficia.info/actualite-musique/inna-decouvrez-heaven-nouveau-single-aux-multiples-influences/61642|accessdate=1 July 2016|publisher=Aficia|trans-title=Inna: "Heaven", her new single with multiple influences!|language=French}} However, in an interview with Romanian station [[Kiss FM (Romania)|Kiss FM]], Inna explained that the chorus is written in a language created by her and her label Global Records, further stating that, "At Global Records, we stay so much together that we don't understand ourselves in Romanian, but also not in any other language. So we thought to create an own language. If the ones from ''[[Game of Thrones]]'' can do it, then why can't we do it as well?"{{cite news|url=http://www.kissfm.ro/article/8061/Inna-despre-Heaven-Refrenul-e-ntro-limb-inventat-de-noi-cei-de-la-Global-Records-|title=Inna, despre "Heaven": "Refrenul e într-o limbă inventată de noi, cei de la Global Records"|trans-title=Inna on "Heaven"; "The refrain is written in a language created by use, the ones from Global Records"|language=Romanian|accessdate=24 November 2016|date=21 June 2016|publisher=[[Kiss FM (Romania)|Kiss FM]]}} ''People Magazine'' called the track a "catchy" [[tropical house]] song that "effortlessly blends together" tropical sounds with a Middle Eastern flair, along with "simple and cheesy" lyrics. Jonathan Currinn from ''Outlet Magazine'' labelled "Heaven" an "exotic anthem",{{cite news|author=Jonathan Currinn|title=Inna captures the essence of summer in new song and video "Heaven"|url=http://outletmag.co/inna-captures-the-essence-of-summer-in-new-song-and-video-heaven/|accessdate=1 July 2016|publisher=''Outlet Magazine''|date=9 June 2016}} while Urban.ro called it a [[dance-pop]] song with exotic elements.{{cite news|url=http://www.urban.ro/muzica/videoclipuri/inna--heaven-videoclip-nou|title=Inna – Heaven (videoclip nou)|accessdate=1 July 2016|publisher=Urban.ro|date=7 June 2016|trans-title=Inna – Heaven (new video)|language=Romanian|author=Scris de Alex}} Radio 21 noted that the track seemed to be influenced by Arabic rhythms.{{cite news|title=Inna lanseaza o piesa de vara – "Heaven"|url=http://www.radio21.ro/inna-lanseaza-o-piesa-de-vara-heaven-videoclip/|accessdate=1 July 2016|publisher=Radio 21|date=7 June 2016|trans-title=Inna releases a summer song – "Heaven"}} Upon its release, the recording was met with mostly positive reviews. ''People Magazine'' praised the song's production, calling it "the perfect track to play at the pool or a beach holiday" and "something different from anything on radio at the moment". Though the review criticized Inna's pronunciation of the lyrics and wished the text was stronger, it concluded: "this is definitely a song that we need on our summer playlist". ''Outlet Magazine'' applauded "Heaven" for "bringing the summer heat" and for being "the ideal song to sit outside and listen to all day long as the sun's rays caress your skin". Urban.ro foresaw it as being successful on radios, and an editor of [[Pro FM]] listed the recording in their list of "16 hits with which Inna made history".{{cite news|url=http://www.profm.ro/stiri/news/muzica/15-hituri-cu-care-inna-a-facut-istorie-31902|title=16 hituri cu care Inna a facut istorie|trans-title=16 hits with which Inna made history|accessdate=10 June 2017|language=Romanian|publisher=[[Pro FM]]}} At the 2017 [[RRA Awards 2011|Radio România Actualități Awards]], "Heaven" was nominated in the Song of the Year, Pop/Dance Song of the Year and Big Like categories.{{cite news|url=http://www.romania-actualitati.ro/nominalizarile_la_premiile_muzicale_radio_romania_2017-101242|title=Nominalizările la Premiile muzicale Radio România, 2017|trans-title=The nominations at the Radio România Actualităț Awards 2017|language=Romanian|publisher=[[RRA Awards 2011|Radio România Actualităț]]|accessdate=13 February 2017}} ==Commercial performance== Following the premiere of "Heaven" on Romanian radio, the song debuted on native [[Romanian Radio Airplay Chart|Airplay 100]] at number 58 on 3 July 2016,{{cite news |url= http://www.kissfm.ro/emisiuni/54/airplay100/ |title=Airplay 100 |date=3 July 2016 |publisher= [[Kiss FM (Romania)]] |agency=[[Media Forest]] |language= Romanian |accessdate= 4 July 2016}} and climbed one position higher the next week. On 17 July 2016, the track rose up 16 places to number 41, reaching its peak position at number four on 16 October 2016. According to statistics by [[Media Forest]], the single was the third most-played recording on Romanian radio on 9 October, while its music video was the sixth most-aired visual on Romanian television. "Heaven" also charted within the top ten on the [[ZPAV|Polish Dance Top 50]] in its fourth charting week, 15 positions above Inna's previous single "[[Rendez Vous (Inna song)|Rendez Vous]]" (2016). According to [[Tophit]], the single reached position 151 in Russia, and number 123 in Ukraine. ==Promotion== [[File:2011-06-26_09-16-48_Mauritius_Rivière_du_Rempart_Cap_Malheureux.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The accompanying music video for "Heaven" was shot in [[Mauritius]] (''pictured'') by John Perez in April 2016.]] To promote the single, Inna performed at a concert in Mauritius.{{cite web |title= Concert: Inna prête à mettre le feu au J&J Auditorium |url= http://www.ilemaurice-tourisme.info/info/Concert-Inna-prte-mettre-le-feu-au-J-ampJ-Auditorium-235.html |publisher= Ile Maurice Tourisme |accessdate=1 July 2016 |language= French |trans-title=Concert: Inna ready to set fire to the J & J Auditorium}} She also sang stripped-down versions of the song for Romanian radio stations [[Kiss FM (Romania)|Kiss FM]] and Radio 21 on 21 June 2016 and 22 June 2016, respectively.{{cite web |title=Inna – Heaven Live @ Radio 21 |url= http://www.radio21.ro/inna-heaven-live-radio-21/|publisher=Radio 21 |accessdate= 24 November 2016 |date= 22 June 2016}} In an interview with Romanian magazine ''Unica'', Inna announced a music video for "Heaven".{{cite news |author=Cismaru, Monica |title= Inna: "Îmi doresc să transmit o stare de bine prin muzică, să aducă bucurie, speranță!" |url= http://www.unica.ro/inna-imi-doresc-sa-transmit-o-stare-de-bine-prin-muzica-sa-aduca-bucurie-speranta-161315|accessdate=1 July 2016|publisher=''Unica''|date=25 May 2016|language=Romanian|trans-title=Inna: "I wish to convey a good feeling through music, to bring joy and hope!"}} The video was previewed in a teaser on 3 June 2016,{{cite web|title=Video Teaser: Inna – Heaven|url=http://zutv.ro/muzica/video-teaser-inna-heaven-id21012.html|publisher=ZU TV|accessdate=1 July 2016|date=3 June 2016|language=Romanian}} and was posted in full on 7 June 2016 on Inna's [[YouTube]] channel. It was shot by John Perez in April 2016 in [[Mauritius]] at the Shangri-La resort. Khaled Mokhtar served as the assistant, director of photography and editor of the clip. Andra Moga did the make-up, while the outfits were procured by RDStyling.{{cite web|title=Inna lanseaza single-ul "Heaven" impreuna cu un videoclip filmat in Mauritius|url=http://topromanesc.ro/2016/06/07/inna-lanseaza-single-ul-heaven-impreuna-cu-un-videoclip-filmat-in-mauritius/|publisher=Top Românesc|accessdate=1 July 2016|date=7 June 2016|language=Romanian|trans-title=Inna releases "Heaven" together with a video shot in Mauritius|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160807151345/http://topromanesc.ro/2016/06/07/inna-lanseaza-single-ul-heaven-impreuna-cu-un-videoclip-filmat-in-mauritius/|archivedate=7 August 2016}} The clip begins with footage from a Mauritius seaside resort community, followed by shots of Inna with a love interest (played by Olivier Phineas Boissard) walking through the city, interacting with locals, and going to a party. Subsequently, Inna is shown from the perspective of the male during a boat trip; the clip ends with her hovering through the sea wearing a yellow dress. Scenes are interspersed of Inna walking on the sea coast while sporting a white and black [[blouse]]. She is also seen performing hand movements in front of a tree and other further footage from the party is shown.{{cite web|title=Inna – Heaven (Official Music {{for|other meanings|Heel (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} In [[professional wrestling]], a '''heel''' (also known as a ''rudo'' in ''[[lucha libre]]'') is a wrestler who portrays a [[villain]] or a "bad guy" and acts as an [[antagonist]]<ref name=torchterms>{{cite web|url=http://www.pwtorch.com/insiderglossary.shtml|title=Torch Glossary of Insider Terms |publisher=[[PWTorch.com]] |accessdate=2007-07-10|year=2000|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606073745/http://www.pwtorch.com/insiderglossary.shtml|archivedate=6 June 2011}}</ref><ref>Foley, Mick. Have A Nice Day: A Tale of Blood and Sweatsocks (p. 2).</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Steel Chair to the Head|last=Sammond|first=Nicholas|page=264|publisher=[[Duke University Press]]|year=2005|isbn=978-0-8223-3438-5}}</ref> to the [[Face (professional wrestling)|faces]], who are the [[hero]]ic [[protagonist]] or "good guy" characters.
To gain [[Heat (professional wrestling)|heat]] (with boos and jeers from the audience), heels are often portrayed as behaving in an immoral manner by breaking rules or otherwise taking advantage of their opponents outside the bounds of the standards of the match. Others do not (or rarely) break rules, but instead exhibit unlikeable, appalling and deliberately offensive and demoralizing personality traits such as arrogance, cowardice or contempt for the audience. Many heels do both, cheating as well as behaving nastily. No matter the type of heel, the most important job is that of the antagonist role, as heels exist to provide a foil to the face wrestlers. If a given heel is cheered over the face, a promoter may opt to [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Turn|turn]] that heel to face or the other way around, or to make the wrestler do something even more despicable to encourage heel heat.
In American wrestling it was common for the faces to be American (e.g. [[Hulk Hogan]]) and the heels to be portrayed as foreign (e.g. [[Alberto El Patrón]], [[Ivan Koloff]], [[The Iron Sheik]], [[Rusev (wrestler)|Rusev]], [[Jinder Mahal]] and [[Muhammad Hassan (wrestler)|Muhammad Hassan]]).
In the world of ''lucha libre'' wrestling, heels are generally known for being brawlers and for using physical moves that emphasize brute strength or size, often having outfits akin to [[demon]]s, [[devil]]s, or other [[trickster]]s. This is contrasted with the heroic ''técnicos'' that are generally known for using moves requiring technical skill, particularly [[Professional wrestling aerial techniques|aerial maneuvers]].
== History == Common heel behavior includes cheating to win (e.g. using the ropes for leverage while [[Pin (professional wrestling)|pinning]] or attacking with [[Glossary of professional wrestling#Foreign object|foreign objects]] while the [[Referee (professional wrestling)|referee]] is looking away), employing [[Professional wrestling attacks#Illegal attacks|dirty tactics]] such as [[Chokes|blatant chokes]] or [[Professional wrestling attacks#Eye rake|raking the eyes]], attacking other wrestlers backstage, interfering with other wrestlers' matches, insulting the fans or city they are in (referred to as "[[Heat (professional wrestling)#Cheap heat|cheap heat]]") and acting in a haughty or superior manner.<ref name=mf117>Foley, Mick. Have A Nice Day: A Tale of Blood and Sweatsocks (p. 117).</ref>
[[File:Gorgeous George robe.jpg|thumb|With his flamboyant gimmick, [[Gorgeous George]] became one of the most famous wrestlers of his era]] More theatrical heels would feature dramatic outfits giving off a nasty or otherwise dangerous look, such as wearing [[corpse paint]] over their faces, putting on demonic masks, covering themselves in dark leather and the like. [[Gorgeous George]] is regarded as the father of the wrestling gimmick and by extension the heel gimmick. Starting in the 1940s, he invented an extravagant, flamboyant "pretty boy" gimmick who wore wavy blonde hair, colorful robes and ritzy outfits and was accompanied by beautiful valets to the ring for his matches. The crowd widely jeered his persona and came out to his matches in hopes of seeing him defeated. He in turn relished in it and exploded in to the one of the most famous (and hated) heels not only of his era, but of all time. Another example of a dramatic looking heel is the wrestler [[The Undertaker]] (in his heel roles). During his period in [[The Ministry of Darkness]], he undertook performances where he would appear as a priest of the [[Occultism|occult]] in a hooded black robe and sit on a devilish throne.
Occasionally, faces who have recently turned from being heels still exhibit characteristics from their heel persona.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.com/Slam/Wrestling/PPVReports/2004/03/15/382634.html|title='WWE WrestleMania XX' Results|last=Powell|first=John|accessdate=2008-03-15|work=Slam! Sports|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]}}</ref> This occurs due to fans being entertained by a wrestler despite (or because of) their heel persona, often due to the performer's charisma or charm in playing the role. Certain wrestlers such as [[Eddie Guerrero]] and [[Ric Flair]] gained popularity as faces by using tactics that would typically be associated with heels, while others like [[Stone Cold Steve Austin]], and [[Scott Hall]] displayed heelish behavior through most of their careers yet got big face reactions, leading them to be marketed as [[Antihero]]es.
On other occasions, wrestlers who are positioned as faces receive a negative audience reaction despite their portrayal as heroes. An example is [[Roman Reigns]], who in 2018 is a top face in [[WWE]], but gets booed in his matches while his opponents gets cheered regardless of them being face or heel, due to [[Persona and reception of Roman Reigns|perceived favoritism from WWE bookers and executive and a lack of character development]]. Such characters often (but not always) become nudged into becoming villains over time or retooled to present a different public image, such as [[Dwayne Johnson|The Rock]]'s heel turn from a clean-cut face to self-absorbed narcissist in the heel [[Nation of Domination]] stable. The term heel does not describe a typical set of attributes or audience reaction by itself, but simply a wrestler's presentation and booking as an antagonist.
Depending on the [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Angle|angle]], a heel can act cowardly or overpowering to their opponents. For instance, a "closet champion" in particular is a term for a heel in possession of a title belt who consistently dodges top flight competition and attempts to back down from challenges. One of many examples is [[Seth Rollins]] during his first [[WWE Championship|WWE World Heavyweight Championship]] run, [[Charlotte Flair|Charlotte]] during her [[WWE Divas Championship|Divas]]/[[WWE Raw Women's Championship|Raw Women's Championship]] reign, [[the Honky Tonk Man]] during his long [[WWE Intercontinental Championship|Intercontinental Championship]] reign, and [[Tommaso Ciampa]] during his [[NXT Championship]] reign. This helps to affirm the intended [[kayfabe]] reactions that the face(s) that said heel is feuding with is/are more deserving of the title. Heels may in fact beg for mercy during a beat down at the hands of faces, even if they have delivered similar beat downs with no mercy, with Ric Flair in particular being well known for this. Other heels may act overpowering to their opponents as to play up the scrappy [[Underdog (term)|underdog]] success story for the face instead. [[Brock Lesnar]] has played heel in both capacities, but has become quite famous (either as a heel or a face) as an [[glossary of professional wrestling terms#monster|almost-unstoppable machine]] who can take down anything in his path.

{{Infobox philosopher |region = [[Western Philosophy]] |era = [[20th-century philosophy]] |image = |caption = |name = James Francis Ross |birth_date = {{birth date|1931|10|09}} |birth_place = [[Providence, Rhode Island]] |death_date = {{death date and age|2010|07|12|1931|10|09}} |death_place = [[Boston, Massachusetts]] |school_tradition = [[Analytic Philosophy]] |main_interests = [[Philosophy of Religion]], [[Philosophy of Language]], [[Philosophy of Mind]], [[Medieval Philosophy]], [[Philosophy of Law]] |influences = [[Thomas Aquinas]] |influenced = |notable_ideas = }} '''James Francis Ross''' (October 9, 1931 – July 12, 2010) was an [[American philosopher]]. James Ross, a creative thinker in philosophy of religion, law, metaphysics and philosophy of mind, was a member of the Philosophy Department at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] from 1962 until his death. He published widely.
==Biography== James Ross was born October 9, 1931, in Providence, Rhode Island, and died in Boston, Massachusetts, on July 12, 2010. He was son of the James Joseph and Teresa (Sullivan) Ross. His father was a pharmacist and his mother a school teacher. In 1956 he married Kathleen Fallon, a nurse from Providence, who died on May 23, 2010.
He received his A.B. (1953) and A.M. (1954) from [[Catholic University of America]], Ph.D. (1958) from [[Brown University]], and J.D. (1974) from the [[University of Pennsylvania]]. He was admitted to the Pennsylvania Bar in 1975. James Ross began his academic career in the Philosophy Department at the University of Michigan initially as an instructor (1959–61) and then as an Assistant Professor (1961–62). In 1962 he joined the University of Pennsylvania and remained there until his death, as an assistant professor from 1962 to 1965, an associate professor from 1965 to 1968, and from 1968 onwards as a full professor. He held a number of visiting appointments including Visiting Lecturer Johns Hopkins (1964–65), the Institute for Advanced Study (Princeton) during the 1975–6 academic year, and Darwin College Cambridge University from September 1982 through December 1983. His research at the Institute for Advanced Study was supported by an NEH grant to the Institute,.<ref>Grant number: FC10503.</ref> He also led a 1977 NEH Summer Seminar at Brown University, titled Faith, Meaning and Religious Knowledge.<ref>National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH) Grant FA-26537-77-163 to Brown University</ref> From 1984 to 1986 he was the president of the [[Society for Medieval and Renaissance Philosophy]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smrphil.org/society.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-09-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328113525/http://www.smrphil.org/society.html |archivedate=2012-03-28 |df= }}</ref>
He researched, taught, and wrote in the fields of medieval philosophy, philosophy of language, law, and religion. In a career that spanned more than five decades, he produced more than 100 articles, a number of translations, and four books. In the last book published before he died, ''Thought and World'' (2008) he argues that meaning, truth, impossibility, natural necessity, and our intelligent perception of nature fit together into a distinctly realist account of thought and world. He articulates a moderate realism about repeatable natural structures and our abstractive ability to discern them that poses a challenge to many of the common assumptions and claims of contemporary analytic philosophy. He develops a broadly Aristotelian metaphysics that recognizes the "hidden necessities" of things, which are disclosed through the sciences.
James Ross' scholarly examination of Analogy began with his doctoral thesis at Brown University (1958), led to such seminal articles as "Analogy as a Rule of Meaning for Religious Language" (1961) and "Analogy and the Resolution of Some Cognitivity Problems" (1970), and eventually to a monograph, ''Portraying Analogy'' (1981), which was the first fundamental examination of the topic since Cajetan ([[Thomas Cajetan]]) in 1498.

Abriol | honorific-suffix = P.A. | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | image_size = 144px | alt = | caption = | sanskrit = | kunya = | religion = [[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] | denomination = | school = | lineage = | sect = | subsect = | temple = | order = | institute = | church = <!-- or: |churches = --> | alma_mater = | other_names = <!-- or: | other_name = --> | dharma_names = <!-- or: | dharma_name = --> | monastic_name = | pen_name = | posthumous_name = | nationality = | home_town = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1918|02|14}} | birth_place = [[Manila, Philippines]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2003|07|06|1918|02|14}} | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|latitude|longitude|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | spouse = | children = | parents = | location = | title = | period = | consecration = | predecessor = | successor = | reason = | rank = | teacher = | reincarnation_of = | students = | initiated = | works = ''Ang Banal na Biblia'' (The Holy Bible, in [[Filipino language|Filipino]]) | ordination = | initiation = | initiation_date = | initiation_place = | initiator = | profession = [[priest]], [[Bible translations|bible translator]] | previous_post = | present_post = | post = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | background = <!-- optional header background color --> }} '''Rev. Msgr. Jose C. Abriol''' (February 4, 1918 – July 6, 2003) was a [[Filipino people|Filipino]] [[Catholic priest]], linguist, and high official in the church in the [[Philippines]]. He was the first to [[Bible translation|translate]] the [[Bible]] into [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]], the native language for most Filipinos.<ref name="RCam2">[http://www.rcam.org/news/2004/joseabriol.htm Msgr. Jose Abriol: A Great Church Intellectual Passes Away] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110527032410/http://www.rcam.org/news/2004/joseabriol.htm|date=2011-05-27}}, The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Manila website, RCam.org</ref>
==Biography== Abriol was ordained to the [[priesthood]] on May 14, 1942. He translated the [[Holy Bible]] from the original [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] and [[Greek language|Greek]]. Apart from this, he also became the [[Rector (ecclesiastical)|rector]] of the [[Manila Cathedral]] from 1962 to 1975, and at the same time was the [[chancellor]] of the [[Archdiocese of Manila]]. He was fluent in nine languages, namely [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Latin language|Latin]], Greek, Hebrew, [[Italian language|Italian]], [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]],<ref name="ManilaStandard">Macairan, Evelyn Z. [http://www.manilastandardtoday.com/?page=news04_july09_2003 Msgr. Abriol, Church Intellectual, Dies at 85], News, ManilaStandardToday.com</ref> and [[Filipino language|Filipino]] ([[Tagalog language|Tagalog]]). He served as a priest for sixty years and died at the age of 85. He is regarded as one of the "great intellectuals of the Philippine Church and the world."<ref name=RCam2/><ref name=ManilaStandard/>
==As a translator== As a priest who yearned to propagate the [[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] faith in the Philippines,<ref name=CyberD/> Abriol wrote and translated hundreds of books and [[novenas]] into the Filipino language. Among his works are the very first translation of the complete books of the [[Biblical canon#Western Church|Catholic Bible]] into [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]] (also known as Pilipino<ref name=RCam2/><ref name=ManilaStandard/>),<ref name="MCathedral">[http://www.manilacathedral.org/rectors/abriol.htm Msgr. Jose C. Abriol (1962-1975)], Minor Basilica of the Immaculate Concepcion, Metropolitan Cathedral of Manila, ManilaCathedral.org</ref><ref name="MC2">[http://www.manilacathedral.org/Rectors/rectors_2.htm Jose C. Abriol], official website of the Manila Metropolitan Cathedral-Basilica, ManilaCathedral.org</ref> literature on Roman Catholic [[Cathecism]], the [[Order of Mass]] and the rest of the [[Roman Missal]], and the [[Lectionary]]. He translated the Holy Bible from the original Hebrew and Greek while serving as rector of the [[Cathedral of Manila]], a period encompassing ten years of his life. From 1953 to 1963, he allotted five hours a day for this task.<ref name=MCathedral/><ref name=MC2/><ref name=RCam2/><ref name=ManilaStandard/> Among the 69 to 70 books he authored – excluding his other translation works – were lives of saints, prayers to the [[Virgin Mary]], Sunday [[missals]], the ''[[Via Crucis]]'' (or [[Way of the Cross]]), and the ''Siete Palabras'' (Spanish for the [[Seven Last Words]] of Christ).<ref name="RCam2" /><ref name="ManilaStandard" /> Before the year 2000, he was also able to finish his translation of [[Pope John Paul II]]'s [[encyclical]] ''[[Fides et Ratio]]'' (''[[Faith and Reason]]''), which became ''Pananampalataya at Katwiran'' in Tagalog.<ref name=RCam2/>
==As a priest== Apart from being rector of the Manila Cathedral and chancellor for the Archdiocese of Manila from 1962 to 1975, Abriol served as parish priest for the parishes of St. Michael the Archangel at [[Jala-Jala, Rizal]] (1947–1951), of San Rafael, Balut, [[Tondo, Manila|Tondo]] in [[Manila]] (1951–1962), and of the Minor Basilica of the Black Nazarene at [[Quiapo, Manila]] (1976–1993). He was also a member of the Manila Archdiocesan Commission for the Conservation of the Patrimony of the Art and History of the Church, from 1993 through 1999. He was the [[Vicar General]]<ref name=CyberD/> for the Archdiocese of Manila for 38 years<ref name=ManilaStandard/> from 1965 to July 2003.<ref name=MCathedral/><ref name=MC2/><ref name=Museum/> He was also the first director of Manila's Archdiocese Museum<ref name=Museum>[http://www.rcam.org/offices/archives.htm#MUSEUM Jose C. Abriol], first director of the Archdiocese of Manila Museum, RCam.org</ref> which houses his own "personal collections and church treasures" formerly safeguarded inside a bank vault.<ref name=Museum/> While serving as a parish priest at the Basilica of the Black Nazarene in Quiapo, Manila, Abriol established the St. Peter’s Men Society, a group that "defended Catholicism in [[Plaza Miranda]] against anti-Catholics and employed radio technology to communicate and explain the Biblical foundation of the Catholic faith" to the Filipino people.<ref name=Abe>Fr. Abe. [http://thesplendorofthechurch.blogspot.com/2008/10/basilica-of-nazarene-in-quiapo-manila.html Jose C. Abriol, the great Filipino Bible Scholar], "The Statue of St. Peter guards the entrance door," The Basilica of the Black Nazarene, The Splendor of the Church], SplendoroftheChurch.blogspot.com, 2008</ref> Abriol did not retire from the priesthood, nor from his translation and research activities,<ref name=RCam2/> when he reached the mandatory age of 75. He died of [[cardiac arrest]] at the Cardinal Santos Memorial Hospital on July 6, 2003.<ref name=RCam2/> His wake was held at the ''Arzobispado de Manila'' (the Archbishopric of Manila) inside [[Intramuros]], while the interment was held on July 10, 2003 at the Manila Cathedral, with Cardinal [[Jaime Sin]] as the main celebrant of the Mass.<ref name=RCam2/> Abriol was the friend and confessor of Cardinal Sin.<ref name=ManilaStandard/>
==Awards and recognitions==
===In the Philippines=== In the Philippines, Abriol received the ''Gawad Bukas Palad''<ref name=RCam2/><ref name=ManilaStandard/> (literally, the "Open [[Hand|Palm]] [ of the [[hand]] ] Award") in 1999 from the [[Ateneo de Manila University]],<ref name=RCam2/> the ''Outstanding [[Manilan]] Award'' in 2000 from the government of the [[City of Manila]],<ref name=RCam2/> and the ''Gawad ng Pagkilala''<ref name=ManilaStandard/> (or "Recognition Award") in 2000 from the [[Commission on the Filipino Language]]<ref name=ManilaStandard/> (formerly known as the [[Commission on the Filipino Language|National Language Institute]]) of the Philippines for the "propagation and development of the Filipino language".<ref name=MCathedral/><ref name=MC2/><ref name=RCam2/> On October 3, 1999, Abriol – then 81 years old – also became a recipient of the ''Ten Outstanding Elderly of the Philippines Award'' (known in the Philippines as ''Sampung Ulirang Nakatatanda'') because of his religious work and writings that were offered "for the use and edification of the ordinary faithful". The award was given to Abriol at St. Paul’s College in [[Quezon City]].<ref name=CyberD>Mission, Gina. [http://gina.ph/CyberDyaryo/features/cd1999_1007_003.htm Msgr. Jose C. Abriol], one of the ''Sampung Ulirang Nakatatanda Awardees'' (Ten Outstanding Elderly of the Philippines Award): Ordinary yet noble lives], CyberDyaryo, Gina.ph</ref>
==Works== The translation works of Abriol include the following:<ref name=Paulines>[http://www.paulines.ph/products/bookscat_scriptures.htm "Msgr. Jose C. Abriol" (translator of the "Banal na Biblia, Ang" (Holy Bible, The) ], Scriptures, Paulines.ph.</ref> *''Ang Bagong Tipan'' [The New Testament] (translator, 1997) *''Ang Lumang Tipan'' [The Old Testament<ref name=RCam2/>] (translator) *''Ang Banal na Biblia'' [The Holy Bible] (translator, 2000),<ref name=MCathedral/><ref name=MC2/><ref name=RCam2/> {{ISBN|971-590-107-7}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2012}}{{Use British English|date=December 2017}}
'''Katharevousa''' ({{lang-el|Καθαρεύουσα}}, {{IPA-el|kaθaˈrevusa|pron}}, literally "purifying [language]") is a conservative form of the [[Modern Greek|Modern Greek language]] conceived in the late 18th century as a compromise between [[Ancient Greek]] and the [[Demotic Greek]] of the time. Originally, it was widely used both for literary and official purposes, though seldom in daily language. In the 20th century, it was increasingly adopted for official and formal purposes, until minister of education [[Georgios Rallis]] made Demotic Greek the official language of Greece in 1976, and later in 1982 Prime Minister [[Andreas Papandreou]] abolished the [[Greek diacritics|polytonic]] system of writing both for Demotic and Katharevousa.
Katharevousa was conceived by the intellectual and revolutionary leader [[Adamantios Korais]] (1748–1833).<ref>{{cite journal |title=Language as a Factor of National Identity in the Balkans of the Nineteenth Century |author=Stavro Skendi |journal=Proceedings of the American Philosophical Society |volume=119 |issue=2 |date=April 1975 |pages=186–189 |jstor=986634}}</ref> A graduate of the [[University of Montpellier]], Korais spent most of his life as an [[expatriate]] in Paris. Being a [[Classics|classical scholar]], he was repelled by the [[Byzantine]] and later influence on Greek society and was a fierce critic of the clergy and their alleged subservience to the [[Ottoman Empire]].<ref>[http://invenio.lib.auth.gr/record/56228/files/arc-2006-23343.pdf Adamantios Korais, Αδελφική Διδασκαλία, pages 3sq.]</ref> He held that education was a prerequisite to [[Greek War of Independence|Greek liberation]].
Part of Katharevousa's purpose was to mediate the struggle between the "archaists" favouring full reversion to archaic forms and the "modernists".
==History== {{See also|Greek language question}} The first known use of the term ''katharevousa'' is in a work by the Greek polymath [[Nikephoros Theotokis]], in 1796.<ref>[http://www.onassis.gr/enim_deltio/foreign/01/story_05.php The Phenomenon of Diglossia: Language and National Identity], interview with [[Peter Mackridge]]</ref>
Katharevousa was widely used in public documents and whatever was conceived as work of formal activity by Greek scholars. The name ''Katharevousa'' implies a pure form of Greek as it might hypothetically have evolved from ancient Greek without external influences, while in its modern connotation the word has come to mean "formal language".
In later years, Katharevousa was used for official and formal purposes (such as politics, letters, official documents, and newscasting), while Demotic Greek (δημοτική, ''dimotiki'') or popular Greek, was the daily language. This created a [[diglossia|diglossic situation]] whereby most of the Greek population was excluded from the public sphere and advancement in education unless they conformed to Katharevousa. In 1976, Demotic was made the official language, and in 1982 [[Andreas Papandreou]] abolished the polytonic system of writing; by the end of the 20th century full Katharevousa in its earlier form had become obsolete. Much of the vocabulary of Katharevousa and its grammatical and syntactical rules have influenced the Demotic language, so that the project's emphasis has made an observable contribution to the language as it is used today. [[Modern Greek]] might be argued to be a combination of the original Demotic and the traditional Katharevousa as stressed in the 19th century, also with institutional input from [[Koine Greek]]. Amongst Katharevousa's later contributions is the promotion of classically based compounds to describe items and concepts that did not exist in earlier times, such as "newspaper", "police", "automobile", "aeroplane", "television" and many others, rather than borrowing new words directly from other languages.
==Present-day use== The [[Church of Greece]] and other churches of the [[Greek Orthodox Church|Greek Orthodox]] tradition still use Katharevousa in official communications.<ref>Argyropoulou, Christina (2015): Γλώσσα και εξουσία μέσα από ποικίλα κείμενα στην καθαρεύουσα και τη δημοτική μορφή της ελληνικής γλώσσας. ''Έρκυνα: Επιθεώρηση Εκπαιδευτικών'' 7: 52–69.</ref>
==Text sample== This is a text sample of Katharevousa from the ''[[Great Greek Encyclopedia]]'', published in 1930. The text has to do with [[Adamantios Korais]]'s relations with the [[Greek Church]]. It is rendered in Demotic and translated into English.
*'''Katharevousa:''' Ἡ δ' ἀπὸ τῆς Ἑλλάδος ἀποδημία του ἐγένετο πρόξενος πολλῶν ἀδίκων κρίσεων περὶ προσώπων καὶ πραγμάτων καὶ πρῶτα πρῶτα τῆς περὶ ἧς ἀνωτέρω ἔγινε λόγος πρὸς τὸν κλῆρον συμπεριφορᾶς του. Ἂν ἔζη ἐν Ἑλλάδι καὶ ἤρχετο εἰς ἐπικοινωνίαν πρὸς τὸν κλῆρον καὶ ἐγνώριζεν ἐκ τοῦ πλησίον ὄχι μόνον τὰς κακίας, ἀλλὰ καὶ τὰς ἀρετὰς αὐτοῦ, ὄχι μόνον πολὺ θὰ συνετέλει εἰς διόρθωσίν τινων ἐκ τῶν κακῶν ἐν τῇ Ἐκκλησίᾳ ἐχόντων, ἀλλὰ καὶ δὲν θὰ ἤκουεν ὅσα ἤκουσεν ἐκ τῶν ὑπερβολικῶν κατὰ τοῦ κλήρου ἐκφράσεών του.<ref>''Great Greek Encyclopedia'', Vol. XIV, 1930, p. 864.</ref>
:''Hē d' apò tē̂s Helládos apodēmía tou egéneto próxenos pollō̂n adíkōn kríseōn perì prosṓpōn kaì pragmátōn kaì prō̂ta prō̂ta tē̂s perì hē̂s anōtérō égine lógos pròs tòn klē̂ron symperiphorâs tou. Àn ézē en Helládi kaì ḗrcheto eis epikoinōnían pròs tòn klē̂ron kaì egnṓrizen ek toû plēsíon óchi mónon tàs kakías, allà kaì tàs aretàs autoû, óchi mónon polỳ thà synetélei eis diórthōsín tinōn ek tō̂n kakō̂n en tē̂i Ekklēsíāi echóntōn, allà kaì dèn thà ḗkouen hósa ḗkousen ek tō̂n hyperbolikō̂n katà toû klḗrou ekphráseṓn tou.''
*'''Standard Modern Greek:''' Η αποδημία του από την Ελλάδα έγινε πρόξενος πολλών άδικων κρίσεων για πρόσωπα και πράγματα και πρώτα πρώτα, για την οποία έγινε λόγος παραπάνω, της συμπεριφοράς του προς τον κλήρο. Αν ζούσε στην Ελλάδα και ερχόταν σε επικοινωνία με τον κλήρο και γνώριζε από κοντά όχι μόνο τις κακίες, αλλά και τις αρετές αυτού, όχι μόνο θα συντελούσε πολύ στη διόρθωση μερικών από τα κακά που υπάρχουν στην Εκκλησία, αλλά και δεν θα άκουγε όσα άκουσε εξαιτίας των υπερβολικών εκφράσεών του εναντίον του κλήρου.
:''Ē apodēmía tou apó tēn Elláda égine próxenos pollṓn ádikōn kríseōn gia prósōpa kai prágmata kai prṓta prṓta, gia tēn opoía égine lógos parapánō, tēs symperiphorás tou pros ton klḗro. An zoúse stēn Elláda kai erchótan se epikoinōnía me ton klḗro kai gnṓrize apó kontá óchi móno tis kakíes, allá kai tis aretés autoú, óchi móno tha synteloúse polý stē diórthōsē merikṓn apó ta kaká pou ypárchoun stēn Ekklēsía, allá kai den tha ákouge ósa ákouse exaitías tōn yperbolikṓn ekphráseṓn tou enantíon tou klḗrou.''
*'''English:''' His expatriation from Greece was a cause for many unjust judgements about situations and people and mainly for his behaviour towards the clergy, which was discussed above. If he had lived in Greece and been in contact with the clergy and known closely not only its turpitude but also its virtues, not only would he have contributed greatly to correcting some of the problems within the Church, but also would not have listened to all that he listened to due to his exaggerated sentiments against the clergy.

{{nihongo|'''Kazuki Kaneshiro'''|金城 一紀|Kaneshiro Kazuki|extra=born 29 October 1968}} is a [[Zainichi Korean]] novelist who was born in [[Kawaguchi, Saitama]].
Later in his life he acquired Japanese citizenship. Due to early influence from his [[Marxist-Leninist]] father, he studied at the [[Chongryon]]-affiliated elementary school and middle school. Afterwards his father switched his affiliation for [[Mindan]], he instead studied at Hozen High School (保善高等学校) in Tokyo Shibuya. He graduated in Law at [[Keio University]]. With the strong confusions with Chongryon, Mindan, and Japanese politics he wanted to promote an alternative "Korean-Japanese" (コリアン・ジャパニーズ) identity to overcome social obstacles, but later he abandoned this concept.<ref>{{cite news | first=Su-gyeong | last=Kim | script-title=ko:가네시로 가즈키 소설의 매력 |trans-title=The Beauty of Novels by Kaneshiro Kazuki | date=2006-09-01 | url =http://www.cine21.com/Article/article_view.php?mm=003003001&article_id=40977 | work =CINE21.com | pages =2 | accessdate = 2010-04-12 | language = Korean | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120716181232/http://www.cine21.com/do/article/article/typeDispatcher?mag_id=40977 | archivedate = 2012-07-16}}</ref>

'''Laha''' (Chinese: 拉哈, Vietnamese: La Ha) is a [[Kra language]] spoken by approximately 1,400 people out of a total population of 5,686 [[Laha people|Laha]]. It is spoken in [[Lào Cai Province|Lào Cai]] and [[Sơn La Province|Sơn La]] provinces, Vietnam. Laha dialects had been documented in 1986 by Russian linguists and in 1996 by American linguist [[Jerold A. Edmondson]]. Many Laha can also converse in the [[Khmu language]], and Laha-speaking areas also have significant Black Thai ([[Tai Dam people|Tai Dam]]), [[Khang people|Kháng]], Ksongmul ([[Ksingmul language|Ksingmul]], Xinh-mun), and Hmong populations.
Ostapirat (2000) considers the Laha dialects to form a subgroup of their own (Southern Kra) within the Kra branch.<ref name="Ostapirat">Ostapirat, Weera (2000). "[http://sealang.net/sala/archives/pdf4/weera2000proto.pdf Proto-Kra]". ''Linguistics of the Tibeto-Burman Area'' '''23''' (1): 1-251</ref>
==Geographic distribution== Gregerson & Edmondson (1997) and Wardlaw (2000) report the following locations of two Laha dialects, namely the Wet Laha and Dry Laha dialects.
'''Wet Laha''' ('''Laha Ung''', ''{{IPA|la˧ha˨˩ ʔuŋ˧˩}}'') of [[Lào Cai Province|Lào Cai]] and [[Lai Châu Province|Lai Châu]] *Tà Mít Commune, [[Tân Uyên, Lai Châu Province|Tân Uyên]], Lai Châu, Vietnam (just north of the [[Black River (Vietnam)|Black River]]) — known as the "Wet Laha". Edmondson's informant is from Bản Muot Village, Tà Mít Commune (Edmondson & Gregerson 1997). There are 8 Laha villages numbering no more than 1,000 people in [[Than Uyên District]], Lai Châu, Vietnam. *Pha Mu Commune, Than Uyên and Nặm Cần Commune, Tân Uyên, Lai Châu
'''Dry Laha''' ('''Laha Phlao''') of [[Sơn La Province|Sơn La]] — around the [[Black River (Vietnam)|Sông Đà]] and Nậm Mu Rivers *Noong Lay and Nặm Ét Communes, [[Thuận Châu District|Thuận Châu]], Sơn La, Vietnam (just south of the [[Black River (Vietnam)|Black River]]; in Bản Muot, etc.) — known as the "Dry Laha" *Chiền Xòm, Liềp Tè, Noong Giông, and Nặm Ét in Sơn La *Nặm Giôn, Chiền Xàng, Chiền Dong, Pi Toong, and Mường Bú of [[Mường La District]], Sơn La Province. Laha of Nà Tạy, Pi Toong commune is documented in Hsiu (2017).<ref>Hsiu, Andrew. 2017. [https://sites.google.com/site/msealangs/kra-dai/laha-na-tay Laha (Na Tay) audio word list]. Zenodo. {{doi|10.5281/zenodo.1123351}} ([https://sites.google.com/site/msealangs/kra-dai/laha-na-tay/Laha_PiToong.xlsx?attredirects=0&d=1 word list])</ref> *[[Thuận Châu District|Thuận Châu]], Mường La, [[Quỳnh Nhai District|Quỳnh Nhai]] districts of Sơn La Province *Bản Bung and Phù Yên near Sơn La Province on the north bank of the Black River

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Fsln02logo.jpg|thumb|This [[FSLN]] logo is an example of the [[voseo]] form used in Nicaraguan media.]] --> The official '''language of Nicaragua''' is [[Spanish Language|Spanish]]; however, [[Nicaragua]]ns on the Caribbean coast speak indigenous languages and also [[English language|English]]. The communities located on the Caribbean coast also have access to education in their native languages. Additionally, Nicaragua has four extinct indigenous languages.
==Languages== {{Table of languages spoken in Nicaragua}}
===Spanish=== {{main|Spanish language|Central American Spanish|Nicaraguan Spanish}}
[[Spanish language|Spanish]], or Nicañol as Nicaraguan Spanish is sometimes referred to, is spoken by 90% of the country's population. In Nicaragua the [[Voseo]] form is common, just as in other countries in Central and South America such as [[Argentina]], [[Bolivia]], [[Costa Rica]], coastal parts of [[Colombia]], [[Honduras]] or [[Paraguay]]. Spanish has many different dialects spoken throughout Latin America, [[Central American Spanish]] is the dialect spoken in Nicaragua.
;Phonetics and phonology
Some characteristics of Nicaraguan phonology include: * /s/ at the end of a syllable or before a consonant is pronounced like [h]. * ''j'' (/x/), is aspirated; it is soft as the /h/ in English (e.g.: Yahoo). * There is no confusion between /l/ and /r/, as in the Caribbean. * /s/, /z/ and in some cases /c/ (as in ''cerrar'') are pronounced as [s].
===English===
English is also spoken among Nicaraguans, [[expats]] from the United States and Canada, and widely used by the tourism sector. On the Caribbean coast, due to the African and English heritage, in places like [[Bluefields]] and on the [[Corn Islands]], the English language is spoken in the form of [[English creole]] by the majority of the population there, coexisting with indigenous languages.
==Indigenous languages== [[File:BluefieldsSign.jpg|right|thumb|A sign in [[Bluefields]] in English (top), Spanish (middle) and Miskito (bottom).]] Several indigenous peoples on the Caribbean coast still use their native language, the main languages being [[Miskito language]], [[Sumo language]], and [[Rama language]]. Other Indigenous languages spoken include [[Garifuna language|Garifuna]].
;Miskito Miskito is a [[Misumalpan language]] spoken by the [[Miskito people]] in northeastern Nicaragua along the Caribbean coast, especially in the [[North Caribbean Coast Autonomous Region]]. The Miskito language is the most widely spoken indigenous language in Nicaragua, this is because the Miskito people also hold the highest population of Indigenous people in the country.
;Sumo Sumo (also known as Sumu) is a Misumalpan language spoken in [[Nicaragua]] by the [[Sumo (people)|Sumo people]]. There is wide dialectal variation, and sometimes the major dialects may be listed as separate languages.
;Rama Rama is one of the [[indigenous language]]s of the [[Chibchan languages|Chibchan family]] spoken by the [[Rama (people)|Rama people]] on the island of [[Rama Cay]] and south of lake [[Bluefields]] on the Caribbean Coast of Nicaragua. The Rama language is severely [[endangered language|endangered]]. Their language was described as "dying quickly for lack of use" as early as the 1860s.<ref>Pim, Bedford & Seemann, Berthold (1869). Dottings on the Roadside, in Panama, Nicaragua, and Mosquito. London: Chapman and Hall</ref> By 1980, the Rama were noted as having "all but lost their original ethnic language", and had become speakers of a form of [[English-based creole languages|English creole]] instead, [[Rama Cay Creole]] which is spoken by 8,000–9,000 people.<ref name="CC">Craig, Colette (1990). Review: Dictionary of the Rama Language. International Journal of American Linguistics 56.2:293-304</ref>
[[Language revival]] efforts began in 1980–1981 under the [[Sandinista National Liberation Front|Sandinistas]] however, they were not successful.<ref name="CC"/> The fieldwork for the first dictionary of Rama was done during this time by Robin Schneider, a graduate student from the [[University of Berlin]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Nora Rigby |title=Dictionary of the Rama language: Rama, English, Rama-Creole, Spanish, English, Rama (Speaking with the tiger) |publisher=D. Reimer |location=Berlin |year= 1989|isbn=3-496-00459-2 |oclc= |doi=}}</ref> In 1992, only approximately 36 fluent speakers could be found among an ethnic population of 649 individuals in 1992, of whom only a few scattered individuals live outside Nicaragua. The number of speakers on Rama Cay island was only 4 in 1992, due to language shift to English that engendered [[Rama Cay Creole]].
;Nicaraguan Sign Language [[Nicaraguan Sign Language]] has been of particular interest to [[linguist]]s as one of the few languages whose birth was recorded.<ref>http://www.indiana.edu/~langacq/E105/Nicaragua.html</ref>
==Minority languages== Nicaragua has many minority groups. Many [[ethnic group]]s in Nicaragua, such as the [[Chinese Nicaraguan]]s and [[Palestinian Nicaraguan]]s, have maintained their ancestral languages while also speaking Spanish and/or English. Minority languages include [[Chinese language|Chinese]], [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[German language|German]], [[Italian language|Italian]] among others.
==Extinct languages== Nicaragua has a total of 4 [[extinct language]]s:
;Nahuat [[Pipil language|Nahuat]], also known as Pipil-Nicarao, is a dialect of the [[Nahuatl language]], belonging to the [[Uto-Aztecan languages|Uto-Aztecan language family]]. This language was spoken by the [[Pipil people|Pipil-Nicarao]] people, also referred to simply as the Nicaraos. Nahuat became the [[lingua franca]] during the 16th century.<ref>Fowler, William Roy, The Pipil-Nicarao of Central America, Thesis or Dissertation. Ph.D., Archaeology, University of Calgary, 1981 also published as a book by Univ of Oklahoma Press (June 1989), {{ISBN|0-8061-2197-1}}</ref> A hybrid form of Nahuat-Spanish was spoken by many Nicaraguans up until the 19th century.
;Mangue The [[Mangue language]], also known as Chorotega, consisted of several dialects spoken in western Nicaragua by Chorotega natives. Mangue is a language closely related to the [[Chiapanec language]] spoken in Mexico, and is classified as belonging to the [[Oto-Manguean languages|Oto-Manguean language family]].<ref>Daniel G. Brinton, M.D., Notes on the Mangue; an extinct Dialect formerly spoken in Nicaragua, lecture before the American Philosophical Society, November 10, 1885, published by Proceedings of the American Philosophical Society, Vol. 23, No. 122, (Apr., 1886), pp. 238–257.</ref> In the Monimbó neighborhood of the city of [[Masaya]], there are many Chorotega natives but the language that they speak is Spanish.
;Subtiaba The [[Subtiaba language]] was an [[Oto-Manguean languages|Oto-Manguean language]] which was spoken on the Pacific slope of Nicaragua by the indigenous Subtiaba people (also sometimes referred to as Maribios, Hokan Xiu, or Xiu-Subtiabas). In 1925, [[Edward Sapir]] wrote an article based on scant evidence arguing for the inclusion of Subtiaba in his hypothesized [[Hokan languages]] group. Others have linked Subtiaba to the [[Jicaquean languages|Jicaque]] and [[Tol language|Tol]] languages of Honduras, but it is generally accepted that Subtiaba is an Oto-Manguean language that shares a close affinity with the [[Tlapanec language]] of Mexico. When Sapir wrote about Subtiaba in 1925, it was already very endangered or moribund.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Sapir, Edward |authorlink=Edward Sapir |year=1925 |title=The Hokan affinity of Sutiaba in Nicaragua |journal=American Anthropologist |series=New Series |volume=27 |issue=3,4 |pages=402–435, 491–527 |doi=10.1525/aa.1925.27.3.02a00040}}</ref>
;Matagalpa The [[Matagalpa language]] was a Misumalpan language spoken by the indigenous [[Matagalpa people]]. In 1981, the population of the Matagalpa people was estimated at 18,000–20,000. The Matagalpa people live in the Central highlands of Nicaragua in the departments of [[Matagalpa (department)|Matagalpa]] and [[Jinotega (department)|Jinotega]]. Matagalpa became extinct in the 19th century; the eponymous people now speak Spanish.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | title=Matagalpa | publisher= | url =http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=mtn | work =Ethnologue | accessdate = 2007-09-09 | language = }}</ref> Only a few short word lists remain. It was closely related to the [[Cacaopera language]].

{{About-distinguish2|the language of Rajasthan|the [[Newari language]] of Nepal}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Use Indian English|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox language |name=Mewari |states=[[India]] ([[Mewar]] region of [[Rajasthan]]) |speakers= 4.21 million |date=2011 census |ref=<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.censusindia.gov.in/2011Census/Language_MTs.html|title=Statement 1: Abstract of speakers' strength of languages and mother tongues - 2011|publisher=Office of the Registrar General & Census Commissioner, India|website=www.censusindia.gov.in|access-date=2018-07-07}}</ref> |familycolor=Indo-European |fam2=[[Indo-Iranian languages|Indo-Iranian]] |fam3=[[Indo-Aryan languages|Indo-Aryan]] |fam4=[[Western Indo-Aryan languages|Western]] |fam5=Rajasthani–Marwari |fam6=[[Marwari language|Marwari]] |nation=No official status |iso3=mtr |glotto=mewa1249 |glottorefname=Mewari }}
'''Mewari''' is one of the major dialects of [[Rajasthani language]] of [[Indo-Aryan languages]] family. It is spoken by about five million speakers in [[Rajsamand]], [[Bhilwara]], [[Udaipur, Rajasthan|Udaipur]], and [[Chittorgarh]] districts of Rajasthan state of India. It has [[Subject–object–verb|SOV]] [[word order]].
There are 31 consonants, 10 vowels, and 2 [[diphthongs]] in Mewari. [[Intonation (linguistics)|Intonation]] is prominent. [[Dental fricative]] is replaced by [[glottal stop]] at initial and medial positions. [[Inflection]] and [[Derivation (linguistics)|derivation]] are the forms of [[word formation]]. There are two numbers—singular and plural, two genders—masculine and feminine, and three cases—simple, oblique, and vocative. [[Case marking]] is partly [[inflectional]] and partly [[postposition]]al. [[agreement (linguistics)|Concord]] is of [[nominative–accusative|nominative]] type in the [[imperfective aspect]] but [[Ergative–absolutive|ergative]] in the [[perfective aspect]].<ref>Bahl, KC.(1979). A Structural Grammar of Rajasthani. Chicago: University Press</ref> Nouns are declined according to their endings. Pronouns are inflected for number, person, and gender. Third person is distinguished not only in gender but also in remote-proximal level. There are three tenses—present, past, and future; and four [[Grammatical mood|moods]]. Adjective are of two types—marked or unmarked. Three [[participles]] are there—present, past, and perfect.<ref>Gusain, Lakhan.(2006). Mewari Grammar (LW/M 431). Munich: Limcom Gmbh.</ref>

'''Michel de Pure''', abbott, ([[Lyon]], 1620 – [[Paris]], March 1680) was chaplain and adviser to King [[Louis XIV of France]] (named as such in 1647). Author, translator, he notably wrote a manual on dancing as well as books criticizing the development of [[préciosité]].[https://archive.is/20120803153442/http://www.larousse.fr/encyclopedie/ehm/Pure/181916 Larousse][http://www.universalis.fr/encyclopedie/michel-de-pure/ universalis] He was also appointed [[Historiography|historiographer]] of France in 1653. His name, more than the character, remains attached to the mockery which Nicolas Boileau covered him with. However, in his day, he was recognized for his scholarship."In his time however, Michel Pure was recognized as a learned polygraph, at turn biographer, novelist, poet, playwright, historian, theorist and translator; he wrote in both French and Latin and he also knew Italian". Lise Leibacher-Ouvrard, Daniel Maher, annotated edition of ''Épigone, histoire du siècle futur (1659)'' If Michel de Pure was best known for his valuable book on dance and [[ballet de cour|ballets de cour]] of his time, ''Idée des spectacles anciens et nouveaux'' (Paris, Michel Brunet, 1668), we now know, thanks to the research work of Lise Leibacher-Ouvrard and Daniel Maher, that he also was one of the first authors of [[social science fiction|science fiction novels]], ''Épigone, histoire du siècle futur'' (1659), recognized as "the first true [[Alternate history|uchrony]]". == Works == === Translations === *1663: ''[[Quintilian]]'' *1665: ''L'Histoire des Indes'' by [[Giovanni Pietro Maffei]] * ''Vie de [[Pope Leo X]]'' * ''Vie de [[Paolo Giovio]]'' === Own works === *1658: ''Le Roman de la précieuse, ou les Mystères de la ruelle'', Paris : G. de Luyne, ([http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k123248h 1st, 2nd], [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k123250t/f2.image 3e] and [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k1232516/f2.image 4th parts] at [[Gallica]]). *1663: ''Vita Alphonsi Ludovici Plessaei Richelii, S. R. E. presbyteri cardinalis... Galliarum primatis...'', auctore M. D. P. (M. de Pure), Paris : A. Vitré. *1668: ''Idée des spectacles anciens et nouveaux'', Paris : M. Brunet. Reprint Geneva: Minkoff, 1972. *1673: ''La Vie du mareschal de Gassion'', Paris : G. de Luyne, 4 vol. He also composed some theatre plays: *1658: ''Ostorius'', tragedy ([http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k133224j text online] at [[Gallica]]). *1659: ''La Déroute des précieuses'', mascarade == Bibliography == * Lise Leibacher-Ouvrard, Daniel Maher, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=x7N9Vo_4hY8C Épigone, histoire du siècle futur (1659) Par Michel de Pure]'', Presses de l’Université Laval, 2005 (réédition de l’œuvre de Michel de Pure, accompagnée d’une étude universitaire) == References == {{Reflist}} {{Bouillet}} {{Authority control}} {{Portal bar|French literature|dance|theatre}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pure}} [[Category:17th-century male writers]] [[Category:17th-century French dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:Historiographers]] [[Category:Historical dance]] [[Category:Latin-language writers]] [[Category:People from Lyon]] [[Category:1620 births]] [[Category:1680 deaths]]

In mathematics, the '''Muller–Schupp theorem''' states that a [[finitely generated group]] ''G'' has [[context-free language|context-free]] [[Word problem for groups|word problem]] if and only if ''G'' is [[virtually free group|virtually free]]. The theorem was proved by [[David E. Muller|David Muller]] and [[Paul Schupp]] in 1983.<ref name=MS83>David E. Muller, and Paul E. Schupp, [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/002200008390003X ''Groups, the theory of ends, and context-free languages''.] [[Journal of Computer and System Sciences]] '''26''' (1983), no. 3, 295–310</ref>
==Word problem for groups== {{main|Word problem for groups}}
Let ''G'' be a [[finitely generated group]] with a finite [[Generating set of a group|marked generating set]] ''X'', that is a set ''X'' together with the map <math>\pi:X\to G</math> such that the subset <math>\pi(X)\subseteq G</math> generates ''G''. Let <math>\Sigma_X:=X\sqcup X^{-1}</math> be the group alphabet and let <math>\Sigma_X^\ast</math> be the [[free monoid]] on <math>\Sigma_X,</math> that is <math>\Sigma_X^\ast</math> is the set of all words (including the empty word) over the alphabet <math>\Sigma_X</math>. The map <math>\pi: X\to G</math> extends to a surjective monoid homomorphism, still denoted by <math>\pi</math>, <math>\pi: \Sigma_X^\ast\to G</math>. The ''word problem'' <math>\mathcal W(G,X)</math> of ''G'' with respect to ''X'' is defined as :<math>\mathcal W(G,X):= \{w\in \Sigma_X^\ast\mid \pi(w) =e \text{ in } G \},</math> where <math>e\in G</math> is the [[identity element]] of ''G''.
That is, if ''G'' is given by a [[group presentation|presentation]] <math>G=\langle X\mid R\rangle</math> with ''X'' finite, then <math>\mathcal W(G,X)</math> consists of all words over the alphabet <math>X\sqcup X^{-1}</math> that are equal to <math>e</math> in ''G''.
==[[Virtually|Virtually free groups]]==
A group ''G'' is said to be '''virtually free''' if there exists a subgroup of finite index ''H'' in ''G'' such that ''H'' is isomorphic to a [[free group]]. If ''G'' is a finitely generated virtually free group and ''H'' is a free subgroup of finite index in ''G'' then ''H'' itself is finitely generated, so that ''H'' is free of finite rank. The trivial group is viewed as the free group of rank 0, and thus all finite groups are virtually free.
A basic result in [[Bass–Serre theory]] says that a finitely generated group ''G'' is virtually free if and only if ''G'' splits as the fundamental group of a [[graph of groups|finite graph of finite groups]].<ref>A. Karrass, A. Pietrowski, and D. Solitar, ''Finite and infinite cyclic extensions of free groups''. [[Journal of the Australian Mathematical Society]] '''16''' (1973), 458–466</ref>
==Precise statement of the Muller–Schupp theorem==
The modern formulation of the Muller–Schupp theorem is as follows:<ref name=DW/>
Let ''G'' be a finitely generated group with a finite marked generating set ''X''. Then ''G'' is [[virtually free group|virtually free]] if and only if <math>\mathcal W(G,X)</math> is a context-free language.
==Sketch of the proof==
The exposition in this section follows the original 1983 proof of Muller and Schupp.<ref name=MS83/>
Suppose ''G'' is a [[finitely generated group]] with a finite generating set ''X'' such that the word problem <math>\mathcal W(G,X)</math> is a [[context-free language]]. One first observes that for every finitely generated [[subgroup]] ''H'' of ''G'' is [[finitely presented group|finitely presentable]] and that for every finite marked generating set ''Y'' of ''H'' the word problem <math>\mathcal W(H,Y)</math> is also context-free. In particular, for a finitely generated group the property of having context word problem does not depend on the choice of a finite marked generating set for the group, and such a group is finitely presentable.
Muller and Schupp then show, using the [[context-free grammar]] for the language <math>\mathcal W(G,X)</math>, that the [[Cayley graph]] <math>\Gamma(G,X)</math> of ''G'' with respect to ''X'' is ''K-triangulable'' for some integer ''K''>0. This means that every closed path in <math>\Gamma(G,X)</math> can be, by adding several ``diagonals", decomposed into triangles in such a way that the label of every triangle is a relation in ''G'' of length at most ''K'' over ''X''.
They then use this triangulability property of the Cayley graph to show that either ''G'' is a finite group, or ''G'' has more than one end. Hence, by [[Stallings theorem about ends of groups|a theorem of Stallings]], either ''G'' is finite or ''G'' splits nontrivially as an amalgamated free product <math>G=A\ast_C B</math> or an HNN-extension <math>G=A\ast_C</math> where ''C'' is a finite group. Then <math>A,B</math> are again finitely generated groups with context-free word-problem, and one can apply the entire preceding argument to them.
Since ''G'' is finitely presentable and therefore accessible,<ref name=Dunwoody/> the process of iterating this argument eventually terminates with finite groups, and produces a decomposition of ''G'' as the fundamental group of a finite [[Graph of groups|graph-of-groups]] with finite vertex and edge groups. By a basic result of [[Bass–Serre theory]] it then follows that ''G'' is virtually free.
The converse direction of the Muller–Schupp theorem is more straightforward. If ''G'' is a finitely generated virtually free group, then ''G'' admits a finite index [[normal subgroup]] ''N'' such that ''N'' is a finite rank [[free group]]. Muller and Schupp use this fact to directly verify that ''G'' has context-free word problem.
==Remarks and further developments==
*The Muller–Schupp theorem is a far-reaching generalization of a 1971 theorem of Anisimov which states that for a finitely generated group ''G'' with a finite marked generating set ''X'' the word problem <math>\mathcal W(G,X)</math> is a [[regular language]] if and only if the group ''G'' is finite.<ref>A.V. Anisimov, ''Group languages'' {{icon ru}}, Kibernetika, '''4''' (1971), pp. 18-24</ref> *At the time the 1983 paper of Muller and Schupp was published, accessibility of finitely presented groups has not yet been established. Therefore, the original formulation of the Muller–Schupp theorem said that a finitely generated group is virtually free if and only if this group is accessible and has context-free word problem. A 1985 paper of [[Martin Dunwoody|Dunwoody]] proved that all finitely presented groups are accessible.<ref name=Dunwoody>M. J. Dunwoody, [https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF01388581 ''The accessibility of finitely presented groups''.] [[Inventiones Mathematicae]] '''81''' (1985), no. 3, 449–457</ref> Since finitely generated groups with context-free word problem are finitely presentable, Dunwoody's result together with the original Muller–Schupp theorem imply that a finitely generated group is virtually free if and only if it has context-free word problem (which is the modern formulation of the Muller–Schupp theorem). * A 1983 paper of Linnell <ref>P. A. Linnell, ''On accessibility of groups''. [[Journal of Pure and Applied Algebra]] '''30''' (1983), no. 1, 39–46</ref> established accessibility of finitely generated groups where the orders of finite subgroups are bounded. It was later observed (see <ref>T. Ceccherini-Silberstein, M. Coornaert, F. Fiorenzi, and P.E. Schupp, [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0195669812000492 ''Groups, graphs, languages, automata, games and second-order monadic logic''.] [[European Journal of Combinatorics]] '''33''' (2012), no. 7, 1330–1368</ref>) that Linnell's result together with the original Muller–Schupp theorem were sufficient to derive the modern statement of the Muller–Schupp theorem, without having to use Dunwoody's result. * In the case of [[torsion-free group]]s, the situation is simplified as the accessibility results are not needed and one instead uses [[Grushko theorem]] about the rank of a free product. In this setting, as noted in the original Muller and Schupp paper,<ref name=MS83/> the Muller–Schupp theorem says that a finitely generated torsion-free group has context-free word problem if and only if this group is free.<ref name=MS83/> * In a subsequent related paper, Muller and Schupp proved that a ``finitely generated" graph Γ has finitely many end isomorphism types if and only if Γ is the transition graph of a [[push-down automaton]].<ref>D. E. Muller, and P. E. Schupp, [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0304397585900878 ''The theory of ends, pushdown automata, and second-order logic''.] [[Theoretical Computer Science]] '''37''' (1985), no. 1, 51–75</ref> As a consequence, they show that the [[Monadic second-order logic|monadic theory]] of a ``context-free" graph (such as the Cayley graph of a virtually free group) is decidable, generalizing a classic result of [[Michael O. Rabin|Rabin]] for binary trees.<ref>M. O. Rabin, [http://www.ams.org/journals/tran/1969-141-00/S0002-9947-1969-0246760-1/S0002-9947-1969-0246760-1.pdf ''Decidability of second-order theories and automata on infinite trees''.] [[Transactions of the American Mathematical Society]] '''141''' (1969), 1–35</ref> Later Kuske and Lohrey<ref>D. Kuske, M. Lohrey, ''Logical aspects of Cayley-graphs: the group case''. [[Annals of Pure and Applied Logic]] '''131''' (2005), no. 1–3, 263–286</ref> proved that virtually free groups are the only finitely generated groups whose Cayley graphs have decidable monadic theory. *[[Martin Bridson|Bridson]] and Gilman<ref>M. Bridson, and R. H. Gilman, ''A remark about combings of groups''. [[International Journal of Algebra and Computation]] '''3''' (1993), no. 4, 575–581</ref> applied the Muller–Schupp theorem to show that a finitely generated group admits a ``broom-like" combing if and only if that group is virtually free.
*[[Géraud Sénizergues|Sénizergues]] used the Muller–Schupp theorem to show<ref>G. Sénizergues, ''On the finite subgroups of a context-free group''. Geometric and computational perspectives on infinite groups (Minneapolis, MN and New Brunswick, NJ, 1994), 201--212, DIMACS Ser. Discrete Math. Theoret. Comput. Sci., 25, [[American Mathematical Society]], Providence, RI, 1996</ref> that the [[Group isomorphism problem|isomorphism problem]] for finitely generated virtually free group is [[primitive recursive]]. *Gilman, [[Susan Hermiller|Hermiller]], Holt and Rees used the Muller–Schupp theorem to prove that a finitely generated group ''G'' is virtually free if and only if there exist a finite generating set ''X'' for ''G'' and a finite set of length-reducing rewrite rules over ''X'' whose application reduces any word to a geodesic word.<ref>R. H. Gilman, S. Hermiller, D. Holt, and S. Rees, ''A characterisation of virtually free groups.'' [[Archiv der Mathematik]] '''89''' (2007), no. 4, 289–295</ref> *Ceccherini-Silberstein and Woess consider the setting of a finitely generated group ''G'' with a finite generating set ''X'', and a subgroup ''K'' of ''G'' such that the set of all words over the alphabet <math>\Sigma_X</math> representing elements of ''H'' is a context-free language.<ref name=CSW>T. Ceccherini-Silberstein, and W. Woess, ''Context-free pairs of groups I: Context-free pairs and graphs''. [[European Journal of Combinatorics]] '''33''' (2012), no. 7, 1449–1466</ref> *Generalizing the setting of the Muller–Schupp theorem, Brough <ref>T. Brough, ''Groups with poly-context-free word problem.'' [[Groups, Complexity, Cryptology]] '''6''' (2014), no. 1, 9–29</ref> studied groups with poly-context-free word problem, that is where the word problem is the intersection of finitely many context-free languages. Poly-context-free groups include all finitely generated groups commensurable with groups embeddable in a direct product of finitely many free groups, and Brough conjectured that every poly-context-free group arises in this way. Ceccherini-Silberstein, Coornaert, Fiorenzi, Schupp, and Touikan <ref>T. Ceccherini-Silberstein, M. Coornaert, F. Fiorenzi, P. E. Schupp, and N. Touikan, ''Multipass automata and group word problems''. [[Theoretical Computer Science (journal)|Theoretical Computer Science]] '''600''' (2015), 19-33</ref> introduced the notion of a '''multipass automaton''', which are nondeterministic automata accepting precisely all the finite intersections of context-free languages. They also obtained results providing significant evidence in favor of the above conjecture of Brough. *Subsequent to the 1983 paper of Muller and Schupp, several authors obtained alternate or simplified proofs of the Muller–Schupp theorem.<ref>Y. Antolin, ''On Cayley graphs of virtually free groups'', [[Groups, Complexity, Cryptology]] '''3''' (2011), 301–327</ref><ref name=CSW/><ref name=DW>V. Diekert, and A. Weiß, ''Context-free groups and their structure trees''. [[International Journal of Algebra and Computation]] '''23''' (2013), no. 3, 611–642</ref>

'''Paradiastole''' (from [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] παραδιαστολή from παρά ''para'' "next to, alongside", and διαστολή ''diastole'' "separation, distinction") is the reframing of a vice as a virtue, often with the use of [[euphemism]],<ref name="para1">Silva Rhetoricae (2006). [https://web.archive.org/web/20020817235913/http://humanities.byu.edu/rhetoric/Figures/P/paradiastole.htm Paradiastole]</ref> for example, "Yes, I know it does not work all the time, but that is what makes it interesting."<ref>[http://changingminds.org/techniques/language/figures_speech/paradiastole.htm Paradiastole]. Changing Minds.</ref> It is often used [[Irony|ironically]]. In [[Bible|biblical]] studies, it has come to mean the repetition of disjunctive words in a list. Another example is referring to manual labour as a "workout". Perhaps the most familiar usage today comes from the software world: "It's not a [[Bug (software)|bug]]; it's a feature!" (This is used both euphemistically and literally, as many features in software originated as bugs.<ref>Smallwood and Cantrell (2011), [http://www.cracked.com/article_19262_6-glitches-that-accidentally-invented-modern-gaming.html 6 Glitches That Accidentally Invented Modern Gaming].)</ref>
==Biblical usage== In biblical studies, paradiastole is a type of [[Anaphora (rhetoric)|anaphora]] (the repetition of one word at the beginning of successive sentences). Paradiastole uses a few words—either, or, neither, not, and nor—used as disjunctions.<ref>[http://www.holybibleinstitute.com/files/Bullinger-Figures_of_Speech_used_in_the_Bible_b_.pdf Figures of Speech used in the Bible] , page 2</ref> A ''dis''junction differs from a ''[[Conjunction (grammar)|con]]''[[Conjunction (grammar)|junction]] because it separates things, whereas a conjunction joins them.
An example of this technique can be found in the [[Gospel of John]], clarifying the meaning of τέκνα θεοῦ (God's children):
:οἳ [πιστεύοντες] :οὐκ ἐξ αἱμάτων :οὐδὲ ἐκ θελήματος σαρκὸς :οὐδὲ ἐκ θελήματος ἀνδρὸς :ἀλλ' ἐκ θεοῦ ἐγεννήθησαν. (John 1.13).<ref name="para3">University of York (2006). [http://www-users.cs.york.ac.uk/~fisher/gnt/ Greek New Testament]</ref>
:They [the believers], :'''not''' of blood, :'''nor''' of the flesh's desire, :'''nor''' of a man's desire, :'''but''' of God were born.
In this passage, οὐκ and οὐδὲ (here translated ''not'' and ''nor'') function as the disjunctions. The paradiastole emphasizes that those who believed (οἳ πιστεύοντες) and became "God's children" were not ''physically'' ("of blood", etc.) born again, but ''divinely.''
The French [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] writer [[Voltaire]] remarked sardonically: "This agglomeration which was called and which still calls itself the Holy Roman Empire was '''neither''' holy, '''nor''' Roman, '''nor''' an empire."<ref>Original text: ''Ce corps qui s'appelait et qui s'appelle encore le saint empire romain n'était en aucune manière ni saint, ni romain, ni empire.'' In ''Essai sur l'histoire générale et sur les mœurs et l'esprit des nations'', Chapter 70 (1756)</ref>
